before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"2gc9r","text":"Review the Guidelines section and make sure you have all equipment for keeping Hydra and growing brine shrimp before bringing Hydra into your lab. We recommend writing to a Hydra researcher and requesting the species and genetic lines that you want. Hydra can also be purchased from educational supply companies or collected in the wild.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"b2cna","text":"Hydra is genus of freshwater cnidarian polyp found in lakes, ponds, and streams all over the world. Its remarkable ability to regenerate missing body parts, and even its whole body from fragments, has made Hydra a model system for regeneration and development for over 250 years. Despite their anatomical simplicity, much about Hydra’s basic biology and extraordinary regeneration caption remains mysterious.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4s3ra","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7un79","text":"The simplicity of caring for and doing experiments on Hydra makes it an accessible subject for undergraduate research, high school lab activities, or even a home hobbyist. This collection of protocols describes low-cost methods for maintaining Hydra cultures, including step-by-step instructions for preparing media, growing brine shrimp for feeding to Hydra, and caring for your Hydra colonies. We’ve focused on equipment that can be found in most high school and college labs, or consumer products that can be purchased online.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6o2it","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1s17c","text":"Experiments on Hydra can be incredibly simple. Much can be learned from dissecting a Hydra and observing its regeneration. Hydra’s response to varying environmental conditions can also be explored in a classroom setting with minimal resources. These simple experiments can be a bridge to cutting-edge molecular biology and stem cell research. Sequencing of the Hydra genome has opened the door for genetic manipulations and large-scale bioinformatics studies. Transgenic lines with fluorescently-labeled cell types and proteins, including neuron and muscle activity reporters, are available.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1li0s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cjdlg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5v4hl","text":"References:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7cj06","text":" guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"c913f","text":"Tanks for Hydra:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6rdml","text":"Any glass or plastic container can be used to hold your Hydra. Petri dishes can also be used. For small Hydra colonies, we like \"Pruta\" food storage containers from Ikea because they have flat, transparent bottoms and are easy to clean. We recommend filling tanks to half their volume with Hydra medium. Set the lid on top of the container loosely to allow gas exchange.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cbpa9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"66f3j","text":"Handling Hydra:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cm7jf","text":"Use glass Pasteur pipettes to move Hydra around. For Hydra stuck to the surface of a container, do not use suction to pull the Hydra off the surface. You might rip it in half! Instead, gently scrape the animal’s foot off the substrate with the edge of the pipette. Once it is dislodged you can pick it up with the pipette.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"co0i8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5dcjk","text":"Preventing cross-contamination:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":31}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d5832","text":"Some Hydra species and genetic lines cannot be distinguished by eye. For this reason, it is essential to make sure that Hydra do not touch equipment that will be used for more than one species or line.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"alhma","text":"Do not touch the edges of beakers, bottles, or other equipment to any container with Hydra. Hydra can stick to the lip of a bottle and be transferred to another colony.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7t306","text":"Do not return animals used for experiments to colonies.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f9vcu","text":"Follow the cleaning procedure below to scrub and disinfect equipment between uses.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ca9mm","text":"Some equipment, such as Pasteur pipettes, can be labeled for use with only one line. We label the pipette bulbs with the name of the line and are very careful that the pipette is only used for the intended line. Pasteur pipettes can be used repeatedly if disinfected with ethanol between uses.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"250ro","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"257tj","text":"Disposing of Hydra:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fjtr4","text":"Avoid putting live Hydra down the drain. Collect all medium containing Hydra in a container and add household bleach at 10% the total volume of the medium. Wait for 10 minutes, then pour down the drain.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bahjo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dqb5o","text":"Cleaning equipment:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8q2p6","text":"All equipment should be scrubbed with a brush under a stream of tap water, rinsed with DI water, and treated with 70% ethanol (our preference) or 70% isopropyl alcohol to disinfect. You can immerse your equipment in a container of alcohol or use a spray bottle. Set your equipment on a drying rack while the alcohol evaporates. Avoid using soap on equipment that will come in contact with Hydra and Hydra medium.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cm8op","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8ge3g","text":"Types of water: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1tuls","text":"For preparing media and stock solutions, using Nanopure or MilliQ water if it is available. House DI water from a tap in your lab is probably fine, but monitor your Hydra for health issues that might indicate problems with water quality. DI water from the grocery store or pharmacy can also be used for making solutions. Commercial spring water (e.g. Arrowhead) can be used in place of Hydra medium. Avoid using tap water.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"49nov","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"59fk6","text":"Lab environment:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"69mlm","text":"Hydra can be kept at room temperature in the lab as long as it stays below 75°F (24°C). Some experiments may require that your colonies be maintained in an incubator at 18°C. For viewing Hydra while feeding and cleaning, an ideal space will be well lit and have dark countertops. If you don't have dark counter tops, you can use a black paper or plastic mat.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

Getting the quantity right will take some practice.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"22t8p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"84oau","text":"After Hydra eat, it will take 6-8 hours for them to regurgitate pellets of undigested material. A good schedule is to feed your Hydra in the morning and clean their tanks in the afternoon before you leave for the day. You will remove both uneaten shrimp and pellets at the same time.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1hqnt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6gpcu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"eamer","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"96tfp","text":"If you have observed poor health of your Hydra or fouling in the tanks, you might want to clean twice on each feeding day - once 30 minutes after feeding to remove uneaten shrimp, and once in the afternoon to remove pellets.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ci9bp","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"90iuv","text":"Hydra tanks do not have to be perfectly clean. Remember, Hydra's natural environment is a pond, so a sterile environment may not be ideal.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c6hgs","text":"Clean your tanks after every feeding:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"51kf1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3unuq","text":"Clean Hydra tanks to remove uneaten shrimp and regurgitated pellets on the same day that you feed your Hydra. While cleaning, take note of any changes to the health of your Hydra and the accumulating debris in the tanks that might indicate that it's time for a full cleaning (see below).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1n1ds","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1rm7c","text":"Materials:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dq7bt","text":"Hydra medium","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2l3q9","text":"Large glass bowl","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7jb5","text":"Pasteur pipettes and bulbs","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1p0pm","text":"Gently swirl the medium in the tank to dislodge uneaten shrimp, pellets, and other debris. Pour the medium out of the  tank into a large glass bowl. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3fcts","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"crf3o","text":"Add a little more Hydra medium to the tank, swirl again, and pour into the glass bowl. Replace the Hydra medium in the tank with fresh medium.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cf3q8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8f7o8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"7uiqd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4gqqg","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"cd8fs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4k8t3","text":"While dispensing the medium into the tanks, avoid pouring the medium directly on top of the Hydra. Hold the tank at an angle and dispense the medium down the side of the tank.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"83r16","text":"While pouring the medium out of the tank, some Hydra may stick to the side of the tank above the level of the medium. Use the tip of your Pasteur pipette to push the Hydra back into the medium.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7et8m","text":"It's likely that many Hydra were poured off along with the debris into the glass bowl. If there are only a few, or you have enough remaining in your tanks, you can discard the ones you've poured off.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3gr6u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"abp24","text":"If you want to recover these Hydra, a convenient method is to gently swirl the medium in the glass dish then set the dish on your bench until it stops swirling. The Hydra will collect in the center of the dish where they can easily be picked up with a pipette and transferred back into their tank.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8k8cr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a9kgk","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7ip2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2u0vd","text":"If you have only a few Hydra in your tanks, you simply fill a new tank with Hydra medium and transfer your Hydra one by one with a Pasteur pipette.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"E1C817800AE811ECAFDA03636C1F4BBB","height":225,"id":223942,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eo8hi","text":"Figure 6. Hydra collect in the center of the bowl after gentle swirling.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"IMG_0179-0.5.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/g4yiber8x.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/g4ygber8x.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/g4yhber8x.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/g4yfber8x.webp","width":263}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cnds2","text":"Pour discarded Hydra medium into a bottle or beaker and treat with 10% bleach for 20 minutes before pouring down the drain. This is a precaution against releasing Hydra into the environment, which is especially important when you are working with transgenic lines.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cf2ks","text":"Approximately every month, or whenever you observe scum accumulating on the surface of your Hydra tanks, you will need to do a full cleaning of the tanks.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"910j9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5ks8h","text":"Materials:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7kqiq","text":"Hydra medium","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eh0ef","text":"Latex or nitrile rubber gloves","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3dbml","text":"Large glass bowl","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2luln","text":"Pasteur pipettes and bulbs","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7l5j2","text":"With a rubber glove on your hand, use your finger to scrape the Hydra off the surface of the tank until they are floating loose in the medium.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"an6d","text":"Pour the contents of the tank into your glass bowl and swirl to collect the Hydra in the center of the bowl (see Step 8.3 above).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4qejr","text":"Fill a clean tank halfway with Hydra medium. Use a Pasteur pipette to transfer the Hydra back into the tank, being careful to avoid any debris.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b2o0r","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"7ha89","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"41p8k","text":"You may need to pipette the Hydra up and down or transfer them to another container with fresh Hydra medium to get all of the debris off them.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dprp3","text":"Wash the dirty tank by scrubbing with a brush under tap water. Rinse with DI water then spray with ethanol. If you are going to add Hydra directly back into the tank, wipe with a paper towel to remove residual ethanol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"73fjf","text":"As you are feeding and cleaning your Hydra, keep an eye out for any changes in the appearance of the animals that might indicate a decline in health. Make sure to examine your Hydra once per week under a dissecting microscope.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"senc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eiq4","text":"Things to look for:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a9ekm","text":"Tentacles look short and pointy.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cjrgf","text":"Hydra are contracted and don’t extend when left to rest.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6ncio","text":"There is an excessive amount of debris accumulating on the surface of the tank.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"52u6n","text":"Hydra look like they are wearing fuzzy sweaters. This is a sign of a bacterial infection. Hydra normally have colonies of bacteria that live on their feet but sometimes the bacteria can start colonizing other parts of the animals. Usually this requires antibiotic treatment (see protocol below).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2obeo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"45j47","text":"See Figure 2 from Bossert \u0026 Galliot (2021) for a detailed description of the stages of Hydra health degeneration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b0lr7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"47sbk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Bossert P, Galliot B","can_edit":1,"date":"1325376000","doi":"","guid":"9F2D1360FB7C11EBA00763A61A678F12","id":1338,"journal":"The International journal of developmental biology","protocol_id":"0","title":"How to use Hydra as a model system to teach biology in the classroom"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"128ja","text":"Treat infected Hydra with rifampicin:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fa4j5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"711re","text":"These steps are only needed for treating bacterial infections that may occasionally appear in your tanks.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"p1rm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jr2j","text":"Materials:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bggc0","text":"Rifampicin powder","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"qkn7","text":"Dimethyl sulfoxide","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6935j","text":"Serological pipettes","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4497s","text":"Automatic or thumb roll pipette pump","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6mp7k","text":"Screw cap plastic microtubes","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ca4u","text":"Refrigerator","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"44gt2","text":"Prepare rifampicin stock:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e68d9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2ugb9","text":"Prepare    rifampicin stock solution in DMSO by adding the DMSO directly to the bottle of rifampicin.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":8,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"7fqqq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8ube8","text":"For example, if you have a    bottle of rifampicin powder, add    of DMSO.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":27,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":63,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"fpu1j","text":"Cap the bottle and invert it a few times to make sure all rifampicin in the bottle is dissolved.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"","data":{"concentration":"50","error_concentration":false,"guid":"E452DF20FB9411EBA4C6476E0C4F76BC","id":"9102","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":204}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"1","error":false,"guid":"2AA298D0FB9511EBA4C6476E0C4F76BC","id":"89664","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":6}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"20","error":false,"guid":"4DA267C0FB9511EBA4C6476E0C4F76BC","id":"89665","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}}}}

","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":80,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"ak73l","text":"Dilute the rifampicin stock 1:1000 in Hydra medium for a final concentration of 50 µg/mL.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"73uc8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"amsnr","text":"For example, to make  , add   rifampicin stock to   Hydra medium.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":21,"length":1},{"key":3,"offset":28,"length":1},{"key":4,"offset":50,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"f1oeo","text":"Store medium with rifampicin in the dark.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6f747","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"","data":{"concentration":"50","error_concentration":false,"guid":"3C609EE0FBF011EBA00763A61A678F12","id":"9103","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":204}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"A04BCB00FB9611EBA4C6476E0C4F76BC","id":"49589","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"","unit":32}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"1","error":false,"guid":"EFC0D3B0FB9611EBA4C6476E0C4F76BC","id":"89666","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":3}},"3":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"1","error":false,"guid":"FB3E6A90FB9611EBA4C6476E0C4F76BC","id":"89667","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}},"4":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"999","error":false,"guid":"2E4417A0FB9711EBA4C6476E0C4F76BC","id":"89668","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"a700l","text":"Treat infected Hydra:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6ev9f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4cuhj","text":"Use Hydra medium with rifampicin in place of regular Hydra medium. Feed and clean your Hydra on your regular schedule, replacing the medium with fresh rifampicin-containing medium. Store Hydra being treated in the dark.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"blgnt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cunir","text":"Continue treating with rifampicin for at least two weeks. If the infection is still there after two weeks, you can treat for longer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4ec9m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
